title: She's about to become Manchester's most powerful person - this is what she really thinks
text:

When Manchester town hall anointed its new chief executive late last year, the name that emerged was not one many had seen coming. 
Joanne Roney is not an ‘insider’ plucked from the pool of officials in – or formerly in – Greater Manchester who have long eyed up outgoing veteran Sir Howard Bernstein’s plum position. She is not an acolyte. 
Indeed several such figures did not even make council leader Sir Richard Leese’s shortlist. 
Neither does she already head up another major league town hall such as Westminster, Leeds or Liverpool. 
And nor is she a man. 
Consequently many assumed she was being brought in purely to oversee what is often considered the softer side of running a council: children’s services, social care, neighbourhood issues, rather than the headline-grabbing hard-edged regeneration and investment wins that gained Sir Howard national plaudits. 
Leave the building to the big boys. Manchester Town Hall 
As she works out her last few days as chief executive across the Pennines in Wakefield, Roney is fully aware of that view. But there is a glint in her eye. 
Manchester has indeed signalled that it wants more priority given to issues such as homelessness, roads and child protection, she agrees. 
“Manchester city council’s credibility – and I said this in the interview – comes from its core services being good and we know what they are,” she says. 
“My background is in homelessness and I’m excited to see what we can do about that. Read More What's life really like in Greater Manchester? The results of the biggest ever Manchester Evening News survey revealed 
“And obviously your basic services, your neighbourhood services. Transport clearly is a big issue – huge investment going into transport, massive disruption as a consequence. How do you square that off with genuine dialogue with the public that says ‘this is the pay-off’?” 
She says it will also be a priority to get children’s services ‘right’ ahead of their next full Ofsted inspection after being found inadequate in 2014. 
But that doesn’t mean she’s about to be pigeon-holed. 
“When people take that as meaning I’m not interested in the other stuff, that I won’t be doing it, I actually think there’s a gender perspective to that, a stereotyping, and that’s not true,” she says. 
“If something has fired me up – very much so – it’s this view that somehow I’m not going to be dealing with developers or the economic growth agenda. 
“It’s very interesting that, isn’t it?” 
Roney points to a CV that in some ways has echoes of Sir Howard’s own. 
Having joined Birmingham council at 16 as an apprentice, she has now worked her way up to arguably the top local government job in the country. 
A Birmingham City fan, in her home city she gained professional qualifications in housing and went on to be director of housing at Kirklees council, as well as working with the charity Shelter and serving as deputy chief executive in Sheffield. Read More 
There she oversaw the complete rebuild of the Park Hills estate in partnership with Manchester developers Urban Splash, in perhaps what could loosely seen as her answer to Sir Howard Bernstein’s work in Hulme. 
But Manchester was always the ultimate job. 
“Why Manchester? Manchester has always been, throughout my career, the place you went to,” she says, describing Sir Howard as ‘a legend’. 
“It was a hotbed of forward thinking – innovative, good ideas. You always had a connection with Manchester.” 
And just as Sir Howard brokered deals with government, turning it into an art-form in the last two decades, she too has the numbers of permanent secretaries in Whitehall to whom she will keep talking, she adds. 
Sir Howard’s shoes will perhaps not so much be filled, but re-tailored. 
“I’ve been in this game longer than people might realise,” she smiles. “I’m not a complete novice and my little black book has just as many interesting numbers in it as others, I daresay.” 
Nevertheless there are clear differences between her tone and Sir Howard’s at a time when the power play in Greater Manchester is shifting up a gear, ahead of a new mayor and rising public concern over a range of social issues, notably many related to housing. Read More 
She speaks of ‘listening’ on planning and of having an ‘open and honest dialogue’ on affordable housing, of ‘genuine dialogue’ on transport. 
‘Compromise’ and ‘collaboration’ come up repeatedly, in a lexicon generally absent of macho traits. 
Gender is an issue she returns to several times. She does not shy away from the challenges, some of them self-imposed, of being a woman in a such a male-dominated sphere. 
“When the opportunity came up to be chief executive, I had a long chat with myself. ‘Here you are Joanne, you’ve been in this about 400 years, here’s an opportunity to be a senior woman in the most exciting city at a time when local government is entering a completely new phase.’ 
“Why wouldn’t I want to end my career by being at the top of the league, I guess? 
“It’s taken me a while to be comfortable with the honest answer – which is I’m probably more ambitious than I ever acknowledged in myself.” 
It sounds like a very female way of approaching an important job application. Rather than automatically assume you can cut it, instead go through a wretched internal argument about whether you absolutely, definitely can cut it. 
She instantly agrees. 
“There is truth to that and I carry that responsibility very much as well. Read More GMP arrests 22 people in A WEEK in clampdown on Spice dealers in Manchester city centre 
“I wouldn’t say I’m an un-confident or unsuccessful woman and yet you’re absolutely right – through the process I was still feeling that, despite the fact I’ve got a massive track record and huge credibility. 
“One of the nicest things in the interview process, or in fact just afterwards, was when Richard Leese said to me ‘well you’ve certainly got the pedigree, Joanne’. and I thought to myself: I’ve never considered my self as having a pedigree before, but I do. 
“I think women don’t talk enough about the honesty of that or saying: you know what – yeah I was thinking ‘can I do this’ and having all sorts of wobbles about it and actually it’s nonsense, really. 
“Here’s my track record and my pedigree’s as good as anybody’s.” A rough sleeper in Manchester city centre (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
Roney’s knowledge of homes and homelessness could not be more appropriate for a city in which the cost of housing and a rising tide of street destitution are two of the hottest topics in town. 
Speaking from recent experience – she is renting a flat in Castlefield while she first gets to know the city – she admits renting in the city centre is ‘expensive’. 
“It’s an issue,” she admits. 
The council’s affordable housing policy will be one area she will review when she takes up post, she says, along with wage inequality and homelessness. Read More New powers to crack down on car cruising in Stockport given the green light 
In Wakefield the council has run a partnership with the local college that has seen homeless people sign up for various volunteering activities – through a social enterprise – to help them gain confidence and skills. 
Such a move could be something she would look at in Manchester, but first she wants to understand the problem here, which she admits is on a far greater scale than West Yorkshire. 
“It feels to me very much like back in the 80s when I was in Birmingham really, that you start to get people come into the city centres. 
“So I want to know how extensive our outreach is with the actual people who are in Manchester and what are we doing about understanding root causes - and what’s in place,” she says, adding that often the effects of cut services – particularly mental health services – do not make themselves felt for ‘three or four years’. 
She is clearly not shy of weighing into choppy waters, though. 
Without the thorny subject of Gary Neville’s St Michael’s development even being mentioned, she brings it up herself, in answer to a question about her willingness to listen when the public protests against major regeneration projects. 
“The simple answer: well of course I will listen, but that goes two ways as well. 
“I was glad to see Gary Neville paused his proposals to have a rethink about it. Read More How YOU can be part of the opening Manchester International 2017 show in Piccadilly Gardens 
“I often think the answer to this is in design. The answer to what scheme should progress where in what circumstances is often through ‘let’s look again at the designs, let’s see if we can’t compromise somewhere’. 
“But you can’t leave a city like Manchester and just say ‘that’s it’ on the development front, we’re not going do anything else. 
“So there’s got to be some challenge to some sites that need replacing. Keep bits, change bits, which bits do we keep. Let’s talk about it.” 
Roney’s appointment comes at a moment of huge change for both the city and Greater Manchester. 
She admits the success of health devolution - ‘why don’t we say it as it is, this is really ambitious and really difficult and really complicated and utterly right, so all of those things will have me worried’ – will be the biggest, most exciting and most pressing challenge for her, the one that will keep up her up at night. 
But there is also the stability of the overall Greater Manchester project too, with new officials in charge, a new mayor and no Sir Howard, 20 years after the city began its resurgence. 
Admitting the moment is ‘significant’, she insists this is simply the ‘next phase’, before reaching for a tactful football analogy. 
“Of course you have got new players for the next season. 
“It doesn’t mean it’s still not a successful team, does it? Or that the game’s changed or the ambitions have changed, or that anything in terms of the momentum will be lost. 
“It’s just – new players on the pitch.” Like us on Facebook
